questions.question: What is an autoimmune response?
options: When the immune system fails to respond to infections
When antibodies are produced against the body’s own cells
When pathogens are neutralized by antibodies
When T cells kill infected cells
When B cells are activated without an infection
questions.answer: When antibodies are produced against the body’s own cells

questions.question: Which antibody class is involved in activating the classical pathway of the complement system?
questions.answer: IgM and IgG

questions.question: Which of the following is a feature of IgG antibodies?
options: They are produced during the initial immune response
They are the most abundant in mucosal surfaces
They can cross the placenta to provide immunity to the fetus
They are involved in allergic reactions
They are the least abundant in the blood
questions.answer: They can cross the placenta to provide immunity to the fetus

questions.question: Which type of immune cell directly presents antigens to T cells?
questions.answer: Macrophages, B cells, and Dendritic cells

questions.question: What is the characteristic feature of the secondary immune response?
options: It is slower than the primary response
It is stronger and faster than the primary response
It involves a higher number of neutrophils
It does not involve memory cells
questions.answer: It is stronger and faster than the primary response

questions.question: What does opsonization refer to in the immune system?
options: The destruction of pathogens by natural killer cells
The process by which antibodies enhance the ability of phagocytes to engulf pathogens
The activation of T cell receptors
The killing of infected cells by cytotoxic T cells
questions.answer: The process by which antibodies enhance the ability of phagocytes to engulf pathogens

questions.question: What is the role of IgD antibodies in the immune system?
options: Serving as a receptor on the surface of B cells to help in their activation
questions.answer: Serving as a receptor on the surface of B cells to help in their activation

questions.question: What is the primary difference between MHC Class I and MHC Class II molecules?
options: MHC Class I presents antigens to helper T cells, while MHC Class II presents antigens to cytotoxic T cells
MHC Class I presents extracellular antigens, while MHC Class II presents intracellular antigens
MHC Class I is found on all nucleated cells, while MHC Class II is found only on antigen presenting cells
MHC Class I activates B cells, while MHC Class II activates T cells
MHC Class I is involved in autoimmune responses
questions.answer: MHC Class I is found on all nucleated cells, while MHC Class II is found only on antigen presenting cells

questions.question: Which of the following is true about haptens?
options: They are small molecules that can induce an immune response only when bound to larger molecules
They are large proteins that can act as antigens without a carrier
They are always part of bacteria
They activate T cells directly without requiring a larger carrier molecule
They can only bind to IgE antibodies
questions.answer: They are small molecules that can induce an immune response only when bound to larger molecules

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the function of the "constant region" of an antibody?
options: It determines the antibody's isotype (IgA, IgG, etc.)
It increases the specificity of the antibody
questions.answer: It determines the antibody's isotype (IgA, IgG, etc.)

questions.question: What triggers the primary immune response?
options: Exposure to a pathogen for the second time
Exposure to a new pathogen or antigen
Release of cytokines by T cells
questions.answer: Exposure to a new pathogen or antigen

questions.question: Which of the following antibodies is most commonly found in breast milk, helping protect infants?
questions.answer: IgA

questions.question: What does opsonization refer to in the immune response?
options: Coating pathogens with molecules to enhance phagocytosis
questions.answer: Coating pathogens with molecules to enhance phagocytosis

questions.question: What is the role of CD4+ T cells in adaptive immunity?
options: Recognize antigens on MHC Class I
Produce cytokines that help activate other immune cells
questions.answer: Produce cytokines that help activate other immune cells

questions.question: Which molecule is used by T cells to recognize antigens?
questions.answer: TCR (T cell receptor)

questions.question: What is the role of memory B cells in adaptive immunity?
options: Produce antibodies during the initial immune response
Provide long-term immunity by responding to future infections
Present antigens to helper T cells
questions.answer: Provide long-term immunity by responding to future infections

questions.question: What happens when a T cell receptor binds to its specific antigen on MHC molecules?
options: It induces apoptosis of the infected cell
It initiates T cell activation and differentiation
It promotes phagocytosis of the antigen
questions.answer: It initiates T cell activation and differentiation

questions.question: Which immune cells are primarily involved in the clearance of pathogens during a viral infection?
questions.answer: T cells and B cells

questions.question: Which is a characteristic of the humoral immune response?
options: Involves the activation of cytotoxic T cells
Involves the production of antibodies by B cells
Involves the destruction of infected cells
questions.answer: Involves the production of antibodies by B cells

questions.question: Which of the following is a key characteristic of T helper cells?
options: Help activate other immune cells via cytokine release
questions.answer: Help activate other immune cells via cytokine release

questions.question: Which immune molecule is primarily responsible for forming a protective barrier in mucosal tissues?
questions.answer: IgA

questions.question: The major difference between innate and adaptive immunity is:
questions.answer: The specificity of the response

questions.question: What is the primary target cell of HIV?
questions.answer: CD4+ T cells

questions.question: Which protein on the HIV virus binds to the CD4 receptor of host cells?
questions.answer: gp120

questions.question: What is the main enzyme that allows HIV to convert its RNA into DNA?
questions.answer: Reverse transcriptase

questions.question: Which of the following is a hallmark of AIDS?
questions.answer: Decrease in CD4+ T cells

questions.question: Which co-receptors does HIV use to enter host cells?
questions.answer: CCR5 and CXCR4

questions.question: What is the viral load in an untreated person with AIDS typically associated with?
questions.answer: High replication rate of HIV

questions.question: Which class of drugs is commonly used in antiretroviral therapy (ART) to inhibit reverse transcription?
questions.answer: Nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors

questions.question: What type of virus is HIV classified as?
questions.answer: Retrovirus
